etymologies: mid 19th century. From actual + -ist, probably after French actualiste

definitions: A person who believes that the geological past can be explained in terms of processes observable in the present; a proponent of actualism. Compare "uniformitarian". Now chiefly historical.

notes.text: In early use (by misunderstanding): a person who, in denying the cataclysmic changes envisaged by the catastrophists, supposes the earth and its fauna to have remained substantially the same throughout geological history.

definitions: A person who advocates the theory that only what is actual exists; a proponent of actualism.
